section.title: Configure a GlusterFS back end
section.para: This section explains how to configure OpenStack Block Storage to use GlusterFS as a back end. You must be able to access the GlusterFS shares from the server that hosts the cinder volume service.

note.para: The GlusterFS volume driver, which was deprecated in the Newton release, has been removed in the Ocata release.
The cinder volume service is named openstack-cinder-volume on the following distributions:
In Ubuntu and Debian distributions, the cinder volume service is named cinder-volume.

section.para: Mounting GlusterFS volumes requires utilities and libraries from the glusterfs-fuse package. This package must be installed on all systems that will access volumes backed by GlusterFS.

note.para: The utilities and libraries required for mounting GlusterFS volumes on Ubuntu and Debian distributions are available from the glusterfs-client package instead.

section.para: For information on how to install and configure GlusterFS, refer to the GlusterFS Documentation page.

para.emphasis: Configure GlusterFS for OpenStack Block Storage

section.para: The GlusterFS server must also be configured accordingly in order to allow OpenStack Block Storage to use GlusterFS shares:

step.para: Log in as root to the GlusterFS server.
Set each Gluster volume to use the same UID and GID as the cinder user:
step.screen: # gluster volume set VOL_NAME storage.owner-uid CINDER_UID # gluster volume set VOL_NAME storage.owner-gid CINDER_GID
step.para: Where:

listitem.para: VOL_NAME is the Gluster volume name.
CINDER_UID is the UID of the cinder user.
CINDER_GID is the GID of the cinder user.

note.para: The default UID and GID of the cinder user is 165 on most distributions.

step.para: Configure each Gluster volume to accept libgfapi connections. To do this, set each Gluster volume to allow insecure ports:
step.screen: # gluster volume set VOL_NAME server.allow-insecure on
